page.title: 12North Weald School
page.content: At North Weald Primary school in February 1985, there was a fire. It was caused by the school swimming pool pump over heating. It set one class on fire and the rest of the damage was done by smoke and water from the firemans' hoses. In 1678, a man called Simon Thargood, who was a fishmonger, left fifty pounds in his will for the church to build a schoolroom for the children of North Weald. Since then there has only been 3 school buildings. They are all still in existence. The first one is next to the church and still used as a sunday school. The second one is Wylding Tree farm. This was used in the 2nd world war as the church school was too near the airfield. The third school is the one we work in today.
